title: 107_hr4597
content: SECTION 1. IMMIGRATION PROVISIONS. Nonimmigrant aliens can be excluded from receiving visas and admission for nonpayment of child support exceeding $2,500. This amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act aims to enforce child support payments for nonimmigrant aliens legally obligated to do so. The Attorney General may waive the application of clause (i) for an alien if requested by the court or administrative agency handling the child support obligation, or if there are humanitarian or public interest reasons. The amendment allows immigration officers to serve legal process in child support cases on certain arriving aliens, with consideration for humanitarian or public interest concerns. The amendment will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The amendment allows immigration officers to enforce legal obligations for child support on certain arriving aliens through legal process issued by courts or administrative agencies. This amendment applies to aliens seeking admission to the United States. The amendment allows immigration officers to enforce child support obligations on arriving aliens. This applies to aliens seeking admission to the United States. The Secretary of State and Attorney General can be provided with information on nonimmigrant aliens owing child support exceeding $2,500. The amendment enables immigration officers to enforce child support obligations on arriving nonimmigrant aliens owing over $2,500. State agencies must certify these determinations to the Secretary with supporting documentation. The amendments made by this subsection, effective on October 1, 2004, apply to payments under part D of title IV of the Social Security Act for calendar quarters starting on or after that date, with a delay permitted if state legislation is required for State plans approved under section 454 of the Social Security Act. The State plan is not considered non-compliant with section 454 solely because it fails to meet additional requirements before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter after the State legislature's session following the enactment of the Act. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is deemed a separate regular session of the State legislature.
